001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on long coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * a long for state; like {@link PointHash} but faster and maybe not as high-quality. This implementation has
006 * high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would likely not be a good
007 * option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of {@link Coord#hashCode()}, for
008 * instance). At low dimensions, this is a little faster than {@link PointHash}, but this class doesn't slow 
009 * down much at all as more dimensions are used, while PointHash and most other implementations do slow down. You
010 * can also consider {@link IntPointHash} if your input and output types are usually int, since it's even faster.
011 * <br>
012 * This implements {@link IPointHash} and has a long it uses internally for state, exposed by {@link #getState()}.
013 */
014public class HastyPointHash extends IPointHash.LongImpl {
015
016    public static final HastyPointHash INSTANCE = new HastyPointHash();
017
018    public HastyPointHash() {
019        super();
020    }
021
022    public HastyPointHash(int state) {
023        super(state);
024    }
025
026    public HastyPointHash(long state) {
027        super(state);
028    }
029
030    @Override
031    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
032        return (int)hashAll(x, y, state);
033    }
034
035    @Override
036    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
037        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, state);
038    }
039
040    @Override
041    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
042        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
043    }
044
045    @Override
046    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
047        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
048    }
049    
050    @Override
051    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
052        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
053    }
054    
055    public long getState(){
056        return state;
057    }
058
059    /**
060     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
061     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
062     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
063     * <br>
064     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
065     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
066     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
067     * generalized ratio. See
068     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
069     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
070     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
071     * @param x x position; any long
072     * @param y y position; any long
073     * @param s the state/seed; any long
074     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
075     */
076    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long s) {
077        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
078        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
079        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
080        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
081    }
082
083    /**
084     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
085     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
086     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
087     * <br>
088     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
089     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
090     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
091     * generalized ratio. See
092     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
093     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
094     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
095     * @param x x position; any long
096     * @param y y position; any long
097     * @param z z position; any long
098     * @param s the state/seed; any long
099     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
100     */
101    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
102        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
103        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
104        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
105        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
106        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
107    }
108
109    /**
110     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
111     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
112     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
113     * <br>
114     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
115     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
116     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
117     * generalized ratio. See
118     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
119     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
120     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
121     * @param x x position; any long
122     * @param y y position; any long
123     * @param z z position; any long
124     * @param w w position; any long
125     * @param s the state; any long
126     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
127     */
128    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
129        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
130        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
131        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
132        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
133        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
134        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
135    }
136
137    /**
138     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
139     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
140     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
141     * <br>
142     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
143     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
144     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
145     * generalized ratio. See
146     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
147     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
148     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
149     * @param x x position; any long
150     * @param y y position; any long
151     * @param z z position; any long
152     * @param w w position; any long
153     * @param u u position; any long
154     * @param s the state; any long
155     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
156     */
157    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
158        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
159        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
160        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
161        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
162        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
163        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
164        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
165    }
166
167    /**
168     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
169     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
170     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
171     * <br>
172     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
173     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
174     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
175     * generalized ratio. See
176     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
177     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
178     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
179     * @param x x position; any long
180     * @param y y position; any long
181     * @param z z position; any long
182     * @param w w position; any long
183     * @param u u position; any long
184     * @param v v position; any long
185     * @param s the state; any long
186     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
187     */
188    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
189        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
190        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
191        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
192        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
193        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
194        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
195        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
196        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
197    }
198    /**
199     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
200     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
201     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
202     * <br>
203     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
204     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
205     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
206     * generalized ratio. See
207     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
208     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
209     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
210     * @param x x position; any long
211     * @param y y position; any long
212     * @param s the state/seed; any long
213     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
214     */
215    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long s) {
216        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
217        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
218        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
219        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
224     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
225     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
226     * <br>
227     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
228     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
229     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
230     * generalized ratio. See
231     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
232     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
233     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
234     * @param x x position; any long
235     * @param y y position; any long
236     * @param z z position; any long
237     * @param s the state/seed; any long
238     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
239     */
240    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
241        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
242        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
243        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
244        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
245        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
246    }

248    /**
249     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
250     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
251     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
252     * <br>
253     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
254     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
255     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
256     * generalized ratio. See
257     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
258     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
259     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
260     * @param x x position; any long
261     * @param y y position; any long

263     * @param w w position; any long
264     * @param s the state; any long
265     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
266     */
267    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
268        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;

277    /**
278     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
279     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
280     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
281     * <br>
282     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
283     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
284     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
285     * generalized ratio. See
286     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
287     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
288     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
289     * @param x x position; any long
290     * @param y y position; any long
291     * @param z z position; any long
292     * @param w w position; any long
293     * @param u u position; any long
294     * @param s the state; any long
295     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
296     */
297    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
298        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
299        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
300        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
301        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
302        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
303        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
304        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
305    }

307    /**
308     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
309     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
310     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
311     * <br>
312     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
313     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
314     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
315     * generalized ratio. See
316     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
317     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
318     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
319     * @param x x position; any long
320     * @param y y position; any long
321     * @param z z position; any long
322     * @param w w position; any long
323     * @param u u position; any long
324     * @param v v position; any long
325     * @param s the state; any long
326     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
327     */
328    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
329        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
330        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
331        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
332        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
333        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
334        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
335        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
336        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
337    }
338    /**
339     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
340     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
341     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
342     * <br>
343     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
344     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
345     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
346     * generalized ratio. See
347     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
348     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
349     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
350     * @param x x position; any long
351     * @param y y position; any long
352     * @param s the state/seed; any long
353     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
354     */
355    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long s) {
356        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
357        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
358        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
359        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
360    }

362    /**
363     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
364     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
365     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
366     * <br>
367     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
368     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
369     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
370     * generalized ratio. See
371     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
372     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
373     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
374     * @param x x position; any long
375     * @param y y position; any long
376     * @param z z position; any long
377     * @param s the state/seed; any long
378     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
379     */
380    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
381        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
382        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
383        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
384        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
385        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
386    }

388    /**
389     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
390     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
391     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
392     * <br>
393     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
394     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
395     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
396     * generalized ratio. See
397     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
398     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
399     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
400     * @param x x position; any long
401     * @param y y position; any long
402     * @param z z position; any long
403     * @param w w position; any long
404     * @param s the state; any long
405     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
406     */
407    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
408        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
409        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
410        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
411        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
412        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
413        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
414    }
415
416    /**
417     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
418     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
419     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
420     * <br>
421     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
422     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
423     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
424     * generalized ratio. See
425     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
426     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
427     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
428     * @param x x position; any long
429     * @param y y position; any long
430     * @param z z position; any long
431     * @param w w position; any long
432     * @param u u position; any long
433     * @param v v position; any long
434     * @param s the state; any long
435     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
436     */
437    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
438        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
439        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
440        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
441        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
442        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
443        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
444        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
445        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
446    }
447    
448    /**
449     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
450     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
451     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
452     * <br>
453     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
454     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
455     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
456     * generalized ratio. See
457     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
458     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
459     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
460     * @param x x position; any long
461     * @param y y position; any long
462     * @param s the state/seed; any long
463     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
464     */
465    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long s) {
466        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
467        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
468        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
469        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
470    }
471
472    /**
473     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
474     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
475     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
476     * <br>
477     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
478     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
479     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
480     * generalized ratio. See
481     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
482     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
483     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
484     * @param x x position; any long
485     * @param y y position; any long
486     * @param z z position; any long
487     * @param s the state/seed; any long
488     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
489     */
490    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
491        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
492        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
493        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
494        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
495        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
496    }
497
498    /**
499     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
500     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
501     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
502     * <br>
503     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
504     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
505     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
506     * generalized ratio. See
507     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
508     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
509     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
510     * @param x x position; any long
511     * @param y y position; any long
512     * @param z z position; any long
513     * @param w w position; any long
514     * @param s the state; any long
515     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
516     */
517    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
518        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
519        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
520        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
521        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
522        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
523        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
524    }
525
526    /**
527     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
528     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
529     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
530     * <br>
531     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
532     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
533     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
534     * generalized ratio. See
535     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
536     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
537     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
538     * @param x x position; any long
539     * @param y y position; any long
540     * @param z z position; any long
541     * @param w w position; any long
542     * @param u u position; any long
543     * @param v v position; any long
544     * @param s the state; any long
545     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
546     */
547    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
548        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
549        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
550        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
551        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
552        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
553        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
554        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
555        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
556    }
557
558    public static int hash256_alt(final long x, final long y, final long z, final long w, final long seed) {
559        long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
560        return (int) ((0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L
561                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * seed + x)
562                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * x + y)
563                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * y + z)
564                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * z + w)
565                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * w + seed)) * a >>> 56);
566    }
567
568}
